item.title: 10 Flawless Ubisoft Games That Are Perfect From Start To Finish
item.description:
Ubisoft has existed for decades, starting in 1986 as Ubi Soft Entertainment SA. They had a successful series of developed and published games for years, but it wasn’t until the mid-2000s to the 2010s that they really started to take off. Thanks to franchises like Assassin’s Creed , Far Cry , and the Tom Clancy spinoffs, there are a lot of games to love within the Ubisoft brand.

Ubisoft belongs in the top ten echelon of video game companies that most fans would be able to recognize alongside Sony and Nintendo. However players feel about their business practices is not important. Instead, let’s go through the decades and find ten games that represent the best experiences that Ubisoft and its associated studios have developed.

Assassin’s Creed 4: Black Flag

Yo Ho Ho And A Bottle Of Rum

Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag (2013)
9 /10
Released
October 29, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Genre(s)
Action, Open-World
Powered by

Assassin’s Creed 4: Black Flag , for many, is the best game in the Assassin’s Creed series, and it's fun from start to finish. Ubisoft went whole hog on the sailing concept, and between sailing itself and the ship battles, there was nothing else quite as immersive at the time.

Going around to islands to find rare animals to skin and upgrade gear was satisfying too, along with the core assassination missions. Since then, there still hasn’t been a better pirate game than this.

Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist

Building Your Spy Network

Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist
9 /10
Released
August 20, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Drug Reference, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Genre(s)
Stealth
Powered by

Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist continued the work of protagonist Sam Fisher, but retooled the Splinter Cell franchise as a whole. Sam and his team existed in the air, constantly flying to new destinations to do spy work.

Based on mission performance, players could earn money to improve the plane, which would unlock new features. They could also upgrade Sam’s gear, weapon, and tech options, and they were all nicely varied, like a camera that could emit sleeping gas. In the entire series, no Splinter Cell game was this open or made Sam this powerful, which is why it just rules.

Prince Of Persia: The Lost Crown

A Metroidvania Return

Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown
9 /10
Released
January 18, 2024

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood, Mild Language, Violence
Genre(s)
Action, Platformer, 2D
Powered by

Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown was a return to form, of sorts, for the Prince of Persia franchise. The only difference being that it was in 2D and it was also a Metroidvania.

Thanks to the solid platforming, unique powers, and fast-paced action, it was a hit among fans and newcomers. There were features that weren’t typical in Metroidvanias, like a good guiding signal, which helped push the genre forward beyond just being a great Prince of Persia entry.

Scott Pilgrim Vs the World: The Game

Toronto City Ransom

Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game
Released
August 10, 2010

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Cartoon Violence, Language, Mild Blood, Partial Nudity
Genre(s)
Beat 'Em Up
Powered by

Scott Pilgrim vs the World: The Game is still one of the best video game tie-ins to a movie of all time, which also drew in more from the original comics. As Scott, Ramona, or a plethora of other characters, players could go from level to level and beat up enemies across Toronto.

Players could level up their stats by going to various shops and purchasing items akin to the leveling-up system in River City Ransom . With impressive visuals, solid co-op gameplay, and a wicked soundtrack, Scott Pilgrim vs the World: The Game was easily a big hit among fans of the comic and the old-school brawling scene.

Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon

Let There Be Lasers

Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon
8 /10
Released
April 30, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Violence
Genre(s)
FPS
Powered by

Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is one of the most intense shooter experiences anyone could possibly play, and that goes for some of the more ripping Call of Duty campaigns. It’s a complete standalone spinoff to Far Cry 3 , taking place within a futuristic landscape filled with terrorists, dinosaurs, and lots of lasers.

The setting is designed to look like what the 80s assumed the future would be like, including some classics like The Running Man or Escape from New York . It’s also a parody game with plenty of cheesy dialogue and over-the-top action that never overstays its welcome.

Rayman Legends

Platforming Perfection

Rayman Legends
9 /10
Released
August 30, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ due to Cartoon Violence, Comic Mischief
Genre(s)
Platformer
Powered by

Rayman Legends is one of the best-looking Ubisoft games of all time, certainly, with great hand-drawn backgrounds and characters. As the titular Rayman, or any of his friends, players can go through 2D levels to rescue little critters.

The levels are bright, colorful, and inventive, especially the music-based stages. The Rayman franchise helped make Ubisoft what it is today, so it’s a bit sad to see it sit by the wayside with this being the last major console release. That said, it was a high note to end on if Rayman Legends is really it.

Beyond Good And Evil

A Journalist Goes Undercover

Beyond Good And Evil
Released
November 11, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Comic Mischief, Violence
Genre(s)
Action, Adventure
Powered by

Beyond Good and Evil is a smaller and more intimate experience that some players feel is the best game Ubisoft has EVER produced. Taking place within a dystopian society, a journalist, Jade, is seeking to investigate the government and get to the bottom of things.

It’s an action-adventure game, so players can expect some Zelda -like dungeons to explore and fight enemies in. There is also a love of driving, stealth, and photo segments to help keep the game feeling fresh from beginning to end.

Mario + Rabbids Sparks Of Hope

Mario XCOM

Mario + Rabbids Sparks of Hope
8 /10
Released
October 20, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ due to Cartoon Violence
Genre(s)
Strategy
Powered by

Mario + Rabbids Sparks of Hope is a sequel to Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle , which was a good idea for an XCOM -inspired strategy game starring Mario. However, this sequel helps iron out a few kinks and makes combat more enjoyable.

As Mario, his fellow Mushroom Kingdom explorers, and various Rabbid pals, players will go into missions with small squads. Each character has a weapon and a specialty, whether that means sniping enemies or providing area cover. With well-timed placement, characters can combo with each other’s actions, adding an extra layer of strategy that is easy to understand.

Child Of Light

A 2D RPG

Child of Light
6 /10
Released
April 30, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco
Genre(s)
RPG
Powered by

Child of Light is another great-looking game that uses the same UbiArt Framework engine as Rayman Legends . It was a platformer and a turn-based RPG following a princess in a mystical land. With gained allies, players could fight cinematic battles against monsters with every turn displayed on a meter.

With a sound strategy, players could interrupt enemy attacks, but in turn, enemies could cancel their attacks. It was a gamble that made combat more engaging than most turn-based systems at the time, even though it heavily borrowed from the Grandia series.

Valiant Hearts: The Great War

Overtaken

Valiant Hearts: The Great War
7 /10
Released
June 25, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Violence, Blood, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco
Genre(s)
Adventure
Powered by

Valiant Hearts: The Great War is a heartwarming and sad adventure game set during World War 1. Through the eyes of several players, they will have to work their way through battlefields, hospitals, and more.

There is a bit of action sprinkled within, but it’s more like a puzzle game akin to old-school adventure games like Grim Fandango or Monkey Island . The grim aspect may not be for everyone, but the stellar writing is an achievement for video games everywhere, as is the great artwork.

item.title: Games With Mind-Blowing Freedom and Limitless Possibilities
item.description:
Most games offer at the very least a loose direction for players to go into. Some are more linear and strict in how they tell their story, while others are full-on sandbox games where the sky's the limit. Others, still, are immersive sims that strike a balance somewhere in between and encourage players to come up with creative ways to overcome their challenges.

Players who yearn for as much freedom and prefer setting their own goals, rather than being told that they are the Dragonborn who must save the world, have several great games to explore. Whether you enjoy sci-fi universes with galaxies and automation gameplay, or prefer a medieval fantasy world with bosses and dangerous enemies, there's something here for everyone.

Factorio

The Factory Must Grow, And You Choose How

Although the launching of a rocket could be considered a constraining goal in Factorio , ultimately, this game is all about freedom inside a sandbox. Players can play forever, without a clear goal, or even set their own goals, and achieve those in whatever way they see fit. Escape the planet, or don't, basically.

It's the ultimate tech and automation game for builders out there who love to tinker and get creative with no end in sight, all in a sci-fi setting. There are some incredible machines and factories that players can come up with, and easily sink hundreds of hours into the game. Min-max everything, unlock all the research, or be as inefficient as possible with your builds; the choice is yours.

Grand Theft Auto 5

Los Santos Is The Player's Ultimate Playground Of Freedom

GTA 5 may have a story to follow, but ultimately, players can do whatever they want in Los Santos. Forget the main quest or even the side quests; you can become a real menace in the local police force's eyes, explore the vistas, buy some housing and/or cars, and more. Make money, spend it all, and make it all back again, basically.

If all that still isn't enough for you, there are plenty of side activities you can get busy with, from golf to movies, to tennis, and visiting a few very nice ladies at a very nice club. Spend some time at a bar, get yourself a tattoo or a new haircut— GTA 5 is bordering on being the ultimate open-world simulation, and that's all without discussing mods.

Minecraft

Mojang's Sandbox Is Without Parallel In Freedom

Few games out there come with the same freedom as Minecraft . This is THE king of sandbox games, an infinite world of limitless possibilities where nothing is mandatory. Players choose how they want to play, what they want to do, and with all the different difficulty options and settings for worlds, it's also possible to determine the rules of their very environment.

Are you a builder who just wants to decorate? You can do that with a dedicated creative mode that lets you access all the items and blocks in the game. Are you an adventurer who loves to conquer and explore? You can do that by taming a horse, riding a Ghast, or finding an elytra in the end to fly around. Or perhaps you prefer complex factory gameplay or RPG elements? Redstone is the place to start, and for RPG, there's a whole achievement tree and enchantments, and dungeons to slay through.

Valheim

Be The Kind Of Viking You Want To Be

A Viking sandbox survival game, Valheim puts players into a world where the only goal is to survive, and progress from one biome to the next as the challenges grow, and you conquer one boss after another. Beyond that, however, you can play this game in any way that you want and as efficiently as you want.

There's something for everyone here. Builders have a pretty robust system to create rustic bases and grand Viking halls. You can create your own farms, gather resources to create more, or just go out adventuring and exploring what the world has to offer if that's more your cup of tea.

No Man's Sky

A Limitless Galaxy Where You Can Be Whoever You Want

Despite a rocky launch, No Man's Sky has undoubtedly become the gold standard for space exploration and survival gameplay. With a whole open-world galaxy at your doorstep, it's going to be a while before anyone gets bored. It's an infinite world, with infinite opportunities.

And although there's survival gameplay, base-building, and ship-upgrading, there's also a bit of a story to explore, pirates to battle (or become the pirate yourself), and money to be made. You decide the path you take and how long it will take you to get to your desired destination.

Outward

An Unforgiving Survival RPG Where You Choose Your Path

If medieval RPG settings are more your jam, then Outward is the place to start. But wait, this isn't just your typical open-world RPG. It's more like if someone slapped extreme survival mode on Skyrim, with features like sleep and hydration. This is a tough, dark medieval world in the vein of Kenshi , which will require grit for players to get through.

There's absolutely no handholding or direction involved. While there's no base-building, there's pretty deep RPG gameplay, and players are free to explore and traverse through the hazardous world at their own pace. Just make sure to be thoroughly prepared before diving into a dungeon or challenging any tough enemies in the wild.

Rimworld

A Cozy Colony Sim Or A Gritty Survival Strategy, You Decide

Strategy game lovers will find the most freedom in a game like Rimworld , which blends simulation gameplay with base building in a sandbox setting. It's truly an interesting one, because depending on the player, the tone of the game can be quite different. There are pets to tame, but there are also diseases to manage. You can expand the base, or you can focus on tending to the colonists, or a bit of everything.

That's where the freedom comes in: no one tells you how to manage your little colonists. It appeals to both The Sims players with need management, but also to grand strategy or colony sim game fans, as the colonists must be protected from outside threats and their home grows. Every game and world is unique, so the replayability is off the charts.

Project Zomboid

Survive The Zombie Apocalypse The Way You See Fit

Back to something a little grittier and challenging, there's Project Zomboid . Don't let the isometric perspective fool you, because this zombie survival game doesn't take any hostages. It's tough, it's immersive, and the gameplay feels incredibly realistic as you manage your survivor's needs and find a place to build your base. And yes, that includes managing things like boredom and even depression, all real mental dangers of a post-apocalyptic world.

Although the game does force you to survive, you decide how you go about doing this. There's some seriously solid customization in the game, and a bunch of side activities to occupy you that can help you make it through another night and another season. The tasks you complete will directly level them up, reflecting your playstyle. From an extraordinary chef to a fishing expert, you choose how to survive.

The Sims 4

Life Simulation Freedom At Its Finest

In terms of creative freedom, The Sims 4 and the whole franchise, for that matter, are definitely up there. Create whatever kind of household you want by customizing their appearances and traits, and move them into the world, into a house you can build from the ground up. From there on, anything goes.

Does the family want to become filthy rich or terrorize their neighborhood by being mean and spiteful? Do they live in a massive mansion with a butler, or are you opting for a rags-to-riches kind of story? That's all up to the player, and with every expansion, the possibilities grow as new gameplay features from magic to starhood are unlocked.

Kenshi

Freedom At The Cost Of Suffering

Kenshi is not for the faint of heart; let's make that abundantly clear. Kenshi is for those who are not afraid of challenge, of figuring things out on their own, and even then facing failure. It's an unforgiving RPG that has limitless opportunities and incredible depth wrapped into a massive world where you create your character from scratch, but it is unapologetic in how it delivers that freedom to players, to buckle up before you jump in.

Yes, there is freedom, but the world will always hit you with consequences, which adds to the chaos. You might end up enslaved, or you might settle down to be a farmer. Perhaps you wish to hit the road as a trader to sneak around as a thief. Whatever you choose, choose carefully, because you might end up eaten alive by cannibals or imprisoned for life.

item.title: Super Helpful ARC Raiders Cheat Sheet Will Get You to 5 Million Stash Value Before the Expedition Wipe
item.description:
Players who have been stressing about hitting the 5 million stash value to obtain the maximum number of bonus skill points offered by ARC Raiders ' first Expedition wipe can rest at ease, as one super helpful player recently created a detailed guide on how even casuals can accomplish that. In a recent Reddit post by user pRoDeeD, the player offered up the guide as a downloadable PDF, with the post itself featuring images and a list of what is included in the guide. While other players can download the guide for free, pRoDeeD still gives them an opportunity to donate toward their cause of continuing to create valuable walkthroughs for the ARC Raiders community.

This isn't the first guide created and offered by pRoDeeD, as their previous efforts include guides on what to sell and recycle in ARC Raiders , where to use every keycard, and what loot to keep for quests and workshop upgrades. In the weeks since ARC Raiders ' launch, the player has become renowned on the game's subreddit for their helpful tips and the amount of work they put into making each guide. However, their latest guide might be one of their most essential yet, as ARC Raiders ' recent Expedition rewards reveal had many players up in arms about the cost of its bonus skill points.

ARC Raiders' Bonus Expedition Skill Points Have Caused Quite a Stir

It has always been known that the number of bonus skill points players receive from ARC Raiders ' optional Expedition wipe would be tied to the total value of items in their stash, Coins included. It wasn't until somewhat recently, though, that Embark revealed it would take a whopping 5,000,000 Coins-worth of stash value for players to be granted the maximum number of 5 bonus skill points being offered—for a total of 1 skill point per 1,000,000 stash value. By hoarding some of ARC Raiders ' most valuable items, then, players can get closer to acquiring every bonus skill point available when the first Expedition wipe occurs.

Naturally, this has led to players, who regard those bonus skill points as worth it, scrambling for unique (and even exploitative) ways to acquire such wealth before ARC Raiders ' first Expedition wipe on December 22, 2025. The only problem is that obtaining that amount of stash value in the game—and in such a short amount of time, no less—is far from an easy task, especially with the threat of PvP looming over players' heads and whether they find the most valuable loot ultimately coming down to RNG. However, thanks to pRoDeeD, there may be hope for them yet.

pRoDeeD's Guide Helps Players Increase Their Stash Value to 5 Million Before ARC Raiders' Expedition Wipe

According to pRoDeeD's guide for reaching 5 million stash value before the first Expedition wipe, the best way for players to do so is to keep an eye out for the Lush Bloom event and then run "basket routes" on the map where the event is active. Each basket offers around 10,000 Coins-worth of items, and if players do it right, they can earn up to 600,000 Coins per hour by staying in the marked area of pRoDeeD's provided map and extracting as soon as they finish the loop. Once the event is over, players then switch to ARC Raiders ' Stella Montis map, where they loot the containers in the areas pRoDeeD has circled before extracting.

Here is pRoDeeD's ARC Raiders 5 million stash value method in a nutshell:

  • Do ARC Raiders ' Lush Bloom event
  • Run marked basket routes
  • Extract and repeat until Lush Bloom ends
  • Run marked Stella Montis container routes
  • Extract and repeat until next Lush Bloom event

There are some caveats to this method, however, as comments mention that ARC Raiders ' Lush Bloom basket routes are generally crawling with players, which can either result in PvP encounters or empty baskets. That being said, the idea behind pRoDeeD's method involves getting in and out of a round as quickly as possible for maximum efficiency, and even if that doesn't net players the intended 600,000 Coins per hour, it seems to be one of the most effective methods out there.

While it's possible to view pRoDeeD's guide on Reddit itself, the text in the provided images is much easier to read on the downloadable PDF.

For ARC Raiders players unsure how to reach five million before the reset, pRoDeeD’s guide offers a straightforward plan that brings the goal back within reach. It may be the break many needed as the Expedition wipe draws near if they manage to avoid every other player who will likely be taking advantage of pRoDeeD's efforts as well.

10 /10

ARC Raiders

Follow
Followed
Extraction
Shooter
Third-Person Shooter
Survival
Systems

Top Critic Avg: 87 /100 Critics Rec: 92%
Released

WHERE TO PLAY

item.title: What Happens to WB Games IF Netflix Acquires It?
item.description: Mortal Kombat, Batman: Arkham, Lego…Everything! Warner Brothers Games has weather multiple mergers and acquisitions but this latest attempt from Netflix could be their best opportunity in years, or the beginning of the end.

item.title: Games Where The World Reacts To EVERYTHING You Do
item.description:
Some games are more immersive than others. For example, a big open-world game like Red Dead Redemption 2 can make players feel like they are in the Old West, or a game like Minecraft can provide endless hours of content that make time pass by in an instant. Then there are some games that pay more attention than most, and in this way, they create a deeper level of immersion.

Perhaps a narrator is laying out a person’s moves, or NPCs reacting in realistic ways to a player’s actions. Whatever the case may be, for anyone who wants a gaming experience to feel next level, these are some go-to examples of games that will react to everything you do.

Fallout: New Vegas

Remembering Your Dark Deeds

Fallout: New Vegas
8 /10
Released
October 19, 2010

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Developer(s)
Obsidian Entertainment
Genre(s)
RPG
Powered by

Fallout: New Vegas is a big open-world RPG that tracks what players do and say to NPCs. If they go into a town and slaughter all the NPCs living there, the game will take that bad Karma into account, and the same is true if players help NPCs in the world.

There are Factions to join as well, which can affect alignment and may cause NPCs to say different dialogue lines if players are part of Caesar’s Legion, for example. Overall, what players do will either make their character a savior or a baddie, but it will always have an effect of some kind.

Bastion

An All-Knowing Narrator

Bastion
10 /10
Released
July 20, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10 For Everyone 10+ Due To Animated Blood, Fantasy Violence, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco
Developer(s)
Supergiant Games
Genre(s)
Action RPG
Powered by

Before they were known for Hades , Supergiant Games got their start with Bastion , a top-down action RPG known for its colorful artwork, weapon variety, and how the world created itself in front of players inside of dungeons. Most notably, there was a narrator who narrated everything players did, from attacking with a certain weapon to sitting idly by.

Supergiant Games expanded the idea of the omnipresent narrator in Transistor as well, where the game is narrated by the main character's sword. Yet it all started in Bastion, and for a game from 2011, it has aged like fine wine.

Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater

Stealth-Based Knowledge

Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater
Released
August 28, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood, Sexual Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Konami
Genre(s)
Shooter, Adventure, Stealth
Powered by

Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater is a remake of a classic stealth game with a bit more going on underneath the hood. Even though Hideo Kojima wasn’t involved in the remake, all of his experimental mechanics were left intact.

Players can camouflage themselves by wearing various outfits, which will hide them from enemies, but if Snake makes any noise, those enemies will still react. Players can even use the codec system, and any of Naked Snake’s team members may comment on what they are doing, from a recent meal they ate to a certain type of gun they have equipped.

Hitman: World Of Assassination

Eyes On The Barcode

Hitman World of Assassination
Released
January 20, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Use Of Drugs And Alcohol, Blood, Strong Language, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Drug Reference
Developer(s)
IO Interactive
Genre(s)
Stealth, Action, Adventure
Powered by

Hitman: World of Assassination is a collection of missions from the three recent Hitman games, acting as a sort of HUB launcher. On missions, players can get close to their targets by wearing various disguises, which will, in turn, affect how NPCs treat the protagonist, Agent 47.

If he looks like a drummer, people may be in awe of a rockstar, but if he is a waiter wandering where he shouldn’t be, guards may get suspicious. Finding the right disguise and route is why fans love this recent trilogy, as it encourages experimentation and creativity.

Undertale

The Game Sees All

Undertale
Released
September 15, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ for Everyone 10+: Fantasy Violence, Mild Blood, Mild Language, Simulated Gambling, Use of Tobacco
Developer(s)
Toby Fox
Genre(s)
RPG
Powered by

Undertale is a turn-based RPG with a little bit of a twist. Players can choose to play it like a normal RPG, or they can spare all the monsters they encounter to get a better, more altruistic ending. The interesting part is that the game internally keeps tabs on their choices.

For example, if players save the game, do something bad to an enemy, and then reload before that decision was made, the game will remember it. Choices will also carry over after completing one playthrough and starting a new one, as the game is constantly looking for ways to break the fourth wall.

Dishonored

Beware Of Rats

Dishonored
9 /10
Released
October 9, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Arkane Studios
Genre(s)
Action, Adventure, Stealth
Powered by

Dishonored is a first-person stealth game that takes place in a steampunk fantasy world. Players can choose to incapacitate guards with different powers, or they can kill them outright. While it might be easier to stab a guard in the neck and be done with it, the game will make things much harder if players choose to become Jack the Ripper’s cousin.

The more enemies that players kill, the more the city will be infested with rats. These pests carry disease, can block pathways from being as accessible, and have an influence on the game's ending. That’s the major way that Dishonored keeps tabs on players, but like all stealth games, guards will also react to noises or if players appear where they shouldn’t be.

Baba Is You

Change The Meaning

Baba Is You
Released
March 13, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
e
Developer(s)
Hempuli
Genre(s)
Puzzle
Powered by

Baba is You is a puzzle game that's hard to grasp at first until players sort their way through a few levels. Baba is the player character, who looks like a little sheep, and in these levels, there will be a goal and a series of sentences that state what is what.

One could say "Flag is Win," which means reaching the flag means completing the puzzle, whereas another could say "Water is Wall," which would make water impassible like a wall. By removing objects or operator words from these sentences, or replacing them with other objects, players can change the properties of the game to make walls passable or to make another object playable besides Baba, like a rock. Sometimes, there is no one way to win a level, and instead, it's up to the player to create a solution.

Scribblenauts

Word Play

Scribblenauts
Puzzle
Action
Platformer
Systems
Released
September 15, 2009
ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+

Developer(s)
5th Cell
Genre(s)
Puzzle, Action, Platformer
Powered by

Scribblenauts is another word-based puzzle game, but one that is much older, as the original was released on the Nintendo DS. In each level, players are presented with a problem — or example, a cat stuck in a tree — and by using the keypad on the touch screen, players can write in objects that would then appear as objects in the level.

To rescue the cat, players could summon a ladder or perhaps even a firefighter. If players summon the wrong things at the same time, they may choose to fight each other. A cat may chase a mouse or bird, for example. It's a great all-ages game, as there's plenty of fun experimentation to be found, and the visuals are very cartoony.

The Stanley Parable

An Annoyed Narrator

The Stanley Parable
Released
October 17, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ due to Fantasy Violence, Mild Blood, Mild Language, Tobacco Reference
Developer(s)
Galactic Cafe
Genre(s)
Adventure
Powered by

The Stanley Parable is another game with an ever-present narrator, like Bastion , but this is a case where the narrator is a bit antagonistic. At first, players will undoubtedly follow the narrator’s instructions, but since this is a time loop, they may start to branch out after several attempts by going through a left door instead of a right door as instructed.

Doing that will rile up the narrator, and he'll start leading them (or not) down stranger and more absurdist paths, commenting on their actions the whole way. The game itself is a simple walking simulator at its core, but one with tons of humorous content and branching paths that will keep players guessing until the end.
